title: Derry Walls Walk Route

images.title: Eric Jones / The top of Nailors Row from the Double Bastion
images.caption: The top of Nailors Row from the Double Bastion Nailors Row climbing up from the Bogside joins Bishop Street (Without) at Bishop's Gate. The gate can be seen on the left. On the other side of Bishop Street and protected by a high security fence and by CCTV cameras is the Loyalist enclave of the Fountain Estate.

images.title: Eric Jones / St Columb's Cathedral, Londonderry/Derry
images.caption: St Columb's Cathedral, Londonderry/Derry. This Church of Ireland Cathedral was built in 1633. The image was taken from the famous Walls of Derry.

images.title: Eric Jones / View Eastwards along the Grand Parade
images.caption: View Eastwards along the Grand Parade

images.title: Kenneth  Allen / Derry / Londonderry
images.caption: Cannons in line on the walls overlooking Guildhall Square, dating back to the 1600s

description: This walk takes you along the historic walls in the city of Londonderry. Derry is noteworthy as the only remaining completely walled city in Ireland and one of the finest examples of a European Walled City. The Walls were built from 1613-1618 by the Irish Society as defences for early 17th century settlers from England and Scotland. You can follow an elevated path along the Ramparts which provides some excellent views over the city. The trail runs for about a mile taking you past a series of signifcant historical sites including the cannons at the Double Bastion and the 17th century St Columb's Cathedral.
